Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Novel Framework for Knowledge Discovery from Time Series Data in Biology and Climate Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent advances in sensors and high throughput data acquisition technologies have made it possible to collect massive amount of data, and especially time series data in a number of domains (e.g., climate sciences, biological sciences). While a wide range of techniques have been developed for clustering and mining such data, there has been limited progress on scalable algorithms for extracting causal relationships from time series data. This project aims to develop novel machine learning models based on Granger causality to uncover the complex dependence structures from high-dimensional time series. The resulting algorithms will be evaluated in the context of two real-world applications (climate change, computational biology).

The project aims to address three fundamental challenges of data analysis from time series data, including: (1) developing the theoretical foundations of causality analysis from time series data to quantify the gap between Granger causality and true causality, (2) developing a unified framework to incorporate different types of domain knowledge in data analysis, and (3) examining effective solutions to important but usually overlooked practical issues, including irregular nature of the time series and scalability. The resulting algorithms will be evaluated on two real applications, i.e., gene regulatory network discovery in immune systems and climate change attribution, by collaborating with researchers in biology and climate science.

The proposed research could impact multiple application domains where discovery of causal relationships from high dimensional time series data is of interest. The project is expected to advance the theoretical foundations of data analytic techniques for time-series data and provide a unified framework that can easily integrate domain knowledge. The results of this project can be expected to significantly advance the current state of the art in eliciting insights regarding causal relationships from time series data. In addition to the core research advances, this project contributes easy-to-use software based on workflows for teaching machine learning to students, researchers and practitioners with a broad range of backgrounds. Educational and outreach activities include new interdisciplinary courses, workshops, tutorials, and high-school visits. Software and data resulting from this work will be freely disseminated to the broader research and educational community. Additional information about the project can be found at: http://www-bcf.usc.edu/~liu32/uscTimeSeries.htm.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Developing effective machine learning algorithms for analysis and prediction of time series data is a fundamental problem. However, it is an extremely challenging task due to the unique characteristics of multivariate time series data, such as complex temporal dependence relationships, a large amount in streaming fashions, and heterogeneity in resolution and observation length. 

Many excellent efforts have been conducted to address the problem. However, existing solutions either rely on strong assumptions that can be easily violated in practice or end up with complex models which are difficult to scale. This CAREER project investigates novel machine learning models, while leveraging recent advances in statistics, economics, and maths, to achieve both efficiency and effectiveness. We have developed a series of novel frameworks for effective time series modeling, leading to over 30 publications in top conferences in machine learning. Below are some highlights:

Novel deep learning models for time series modeling: deep learning models have achieved significant successes in modeling sequence data, such as languages and biological sequences. However, time series data in broader applications (e.g., climate, health care, traffic etc) exhibit different properties, such as missing value, multi-rate multi-resolution, access to domain knowl- edge, complex dependencies, and etc. In this project, we have developed a series of novel deep learning models to address these challenges, e.g,, hierarchical deep generative models for multi-rate data, DQ-LSTM (Data Quality Long Short Term Memory) for quantifying data quality in time series, D-GRU (Decay Gated Recurrent Units) for handling missing value in time series, generative attention model for capturing relations between time series, and physics-aware graph neural networks for incorporating physics principles. Our paper on D-GRU was among the top 10 of the highly accessed articles across Nature Scientific Reports in 2018 (https://www.nature.com/collections/hgbjhfffcb).

Sparse low-rank tensor regression for spatiotemporal data analysis: Accurate and efficient analysis of multivariate spatiotemporal data is critical in climatology, geology, and sociology applications. Existing models usually assume simple inter-dependence among variables, space, and time, and are computationally expensive. We have proposed a unified low-rank tensor learning framework for multivariate spatio-temporal analysis, which can conveniently incorporate important properties in spatiotemporal data, such as spatial clustering and shared structure among variables. The work was first introduced in NuerIPS 2014, followed by an online learning algorithm via online tensor regression and a memory efficient learning algorithm via subsampled Tensor Projected Gradient. Furthermore, theoretical analysis was conducted to connect our low-rank tensor approach with Gaussian processes; a nonlinear tensor decomposition algorithm has been developed to capture the nonlinear interactions between space and time. 

Granger graphical models for temporal dependence discovery: given multivariate time series data, one important task is to uncover temporal dependence structures, which reveal significant insights into the data and help to build better prediction models. We have developed a collection of machine learning models, namely Granger graphical models (aka temporal causal models), as robust and scalable solutions. Our model is among the first to efficiently uncover sparse temporal dependence structures for high-dimensional time-series data. We have also developed novel extensions of Granger graphical models to address a series of challenges in practical time series, such as non-stationarity, missing value, extreme value, and relational information.

In addition to the aforementioned efforts, we have also worked on continuous time models, time series clustering, time series hashing, time series anomaly detection, life cycle modeling, and time series feature learning. 

Broader Impacts: the research outcomes from this CAREER project have significantly pushed the frontiers of machine learning research in time series - transforming the research from a limited scope of time series forecasting and classification to broader areas, including but not limited to temporal dependence discovery, continuous time models, time series clustering, time series hashing, time series generation and spatio-temporal modeling as well as introducing new challenges, such as missing value, multiresolution, heterogeneity, and multiview. In addition, the developed models have been successfully applied to solving many important problems in scientific domains, such as biology, climate science, social media analysis, and to addressing practical applications in health care, traffic prediction,  and power systems. The PI started the KDD workshop on "Learning and Mining from Time Series" in 2015. Over the past six years, it has grown into one of the most popular workshops in KDD. The PI also co-started the ICML workshop on time series and co-organized NSF workshops on "Real Time Learning" and "Forging Connections between Machine Learning, Data Science, and Power Systems Research". She gave keynote talks in time series related workshops and symposiums. In terms of education, this CAREER project has trained 8 PhD students and 2 Postdocs. A course on machine learning for time series has been developed as a result of the project. Two patents were filed for technology transfer. We have created and maintained a popular data repository for multivariate time series data (https://viterbi-web.usc.edu/~liu32/data.html) and released the code of our work (https://viterbi-web.usc.edu/~liu32/code.html).
